John 3. 29, 30.

Jesus washed his disciples feet, etc. If I then your Lord and Master have
washed your feet, ye also ought to wash one another feet, for I have given you
an example, John 13. 4, 5, 14, 15.

Ye men of Israel, why marvel ye at this? or why look you so earnestly at us,
as though by our own power or holiness we had made this man to walk, etc?
through faith in his name, has made this man strong, Act. 3. 12, 13, 16. chapter
4. 9, 11.

Cornelius met Peter, fell at his feet and worshipped him; but Peter took him
up, saying, Stand up, I my self am a man, Acts 10. 25, 26.

When the Priests of Jupiter and the people would have done sacrifice to Paul
and Barnabas, they said, We are men of like passions with you, and preach to
you that you should turn from these vanities, etc. Acts 12. 13, 14, 15.

Apollos an eloquent man and mighty in the Scripture, yet submits to be taught
the way of God more perfectly by Aquilla and Priscilla Tent-makers, Acts 18.
24, 25, 26.

I have been with you, etc. serving the Lord with all humility of mind, Acts
20. 18, 19.

The Apostle blames the Jews for boasting of the Law, and of their knowledge and
ability to instruct others, etc. Romans 2. 17, 18, 19, 20, 21.

For I know that in me (that is, in my flesh) dwells no good thing, Romans 7.
18.

Boast not against the branches: but if thou boast, thou bear not the root,
but the root thee. Thou will say, The branches were broken off that I might be
grafted in: well, because of unbelief they were broken off, and thou stand
by faith; be not high-minded, but fear, etc. Romans 11. 18, 19, 20, 21.

For I say, etc. to every one among you, not to think of himself more highly
than he ought to think, but to think soberly according as God has dealt to
every man the measure of faith, etc. mind not high things, but condescend to
men of low estate (or, be content with mean things); be not wise in your own
conceits, Romans 12. 3, 16.

God has chosen the foolish things of this world to confound the wise, etc.
that no flesh should glory in his presence, 1 Cor. 1. 27, 28, 29.

If any man among you seems to be wise in this world, let him become a fool
that he may be wise, for the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God, etc.
therefore let no man glory in men, 1 Cor. 3. 18, 19, 21.

That ye might learn in us not to think above that which is written, that no
one of you be puffed up for one against another; for who makes thee to differ
(or, distinguishes thee)? and what have thou which thou did not receive? now
if thou did receive it, why do thou glory as if thou had not received it?
etc. the kingdom of God is not in word but in power, 1 Cor. 4. 6, 7, 20.

If any man think he knows any thing, he knows nothing as he ought to know,
1 Cor. 8. 2.

Wherefore let him who thinks he stands, take heed lest he fall, 1 Cor. 10.
12.

To one is given the spirit, the word of wisdom, etc. but all these works
that one and the self-same spirit, dividing to every man severally, as he will,
etc. The eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee? nor again, the
head to the foot, I have no need of you, etc. 1 Cor. 12. 8, 9, 10, 11, 20, 21.

Charity vaunteth not it self (or, is not rash), is not puffed up, 1 Cor. 13. 4.

I am the least of the Apostles, who am not meet to be called an Apostle, etc.
but by the grace of God I am that I am, 1 Cor. 15. 9. 10.

Not that we are sufficient of our selves to think any thing, as of our selves:
but our sufficiency is of God, 2 Cor. 3. 5.

We have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellency of the power may
be of God, and not of us, 2 Cor. 4. 7.

Some who commend themselves: but they measuring themselves by themselves, etc.
are not wise; but we will not boast of things without our measure, etc. but he
who glories, let him glory in the Lord: for not he who commends himself is
approved, but whom the Lord commends. 2 Cor. 10. 12, 13, 17, 18.

And lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of
revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, etc. 2 Cor. 12. 7.

God accepts no man's person, Gal. 2. 6. Ephesians. 6. 9.

Let us not be desirous of vain glory, provoking one another, etc. Gal. 5. 26.

For if a man think himself to be something, when he is nothing, he deceives
himself, Gal. 6. 3.

Unto me who am less than the least of all Saints, is this grace given, Ephesians. 3.
8.

Walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called, with all lowliness and
meekness, etc. unto every one of us is given grace according to the measure of
the gift of Christ, Ephesians. 4. 1, 2.

Submiting your selves one to another in the fear of God, Ephesians. 5. 21.

Let nothing be done through strife or vain glory, but in lowliness of mind,
let each esteem other better than himself: look not every man on his own
things, etc. Let the same mind be in you which also was in Christ, etc. He
humbled himself, etc. Work out your own salvation with fear and trembling,
Phil. 2. 3, 4, 5, 8, 10.

I know how to be abased, and I know how to abound: Every where, and in all
things, I am instructed, etc. Phil. 4. 12.

Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, etc. humbleness of
mind, meekness, etc. Col. 3. 12.

Let us therefore fear, lest a promise being left of entering into his rest:
any of us should seem to come short of it, Heb. 4. 1.

The rich, in that he is made low; because as the flower of the grass, he shall
pass away, James 1. 10, 11.

Have not the faith of our Lord Jesus with respect of persons: for if there
come into your assemblies a man with a gold ring, in goodly apparel; and there
come in also a poor man in vile raiment; and ye have respect unto him who
wears the gay clothing, and say unto him, Sit thou here, in a good place (or,
well, or seemly); and say to the poor, Stand thou there, or sit here under my
footstool: are you not then partial in your selves, etc. Has not God chosen
the poor of this world, rich in faith, etc? Ye have despised the poor, James 2.
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

My brethren, be not many masters, knowing that we shall receive the greater
condemnation: For in many things we offend all, etc. James 3. 1, 2.

God resists the proud, but gives grace unto the humble. Submit your selves
therefore to God, etc. humble your selves in the sight of the Lord, and he
shall lift you up, James 4. 6, 7, 10.

Likewise ye younger, submit your selves to the elder: yea, all be subject one
to another, and be clothed with humility: for God resists the proud, and
gives grace to the humble. Humble your selves therefore under the mighty hand
of God, that he may exalt you in due time, 1 Pet. 5. 5, 6

Thou say, I am rich, and increased with goods, and have need of nothing:
and know not, that thou art wretched, and miserable, and poor, and blind,
and naked, Rev. 3. 17.

See more Chap. 22, Of submission to God in affliction.

See Death Chap. 33.

To be moderate, meek, patient and quiet in all things: And the encouragements
thereto.
Simeon and Levi are brethren, instruments of cruelty (or, their swords are
weapons of violence): O my soul, come not thou into their secret, etc. for in
their anger they slew a man, and in their self-will they dug down a wall.
Cursed be their anger, for it was fierce, and their wrath, for it was cruel,
Genesis 49. 5, 6, 7. Genesis 34. 25, 26, 27.

Now the man Moses was very meek, above all the men upon the face of the earth,
Mumb. 12. 3.

David had rashly and hastily resolved to have avenged himself upon Nabal and
his house: And he blessed God for Abigails counsel, which hindered him, 1 Samuel
25, 22, 32, 33, 34.

With the froward thou will show thy self unfavoury (or thou will wrestle), 2 Samuel 22. 27.

The meek shall eat and be satisfied, Psalm. 22. 26.

The meek will he guide in judgment: and the meek will he teach his way, Psalm.
25. 9.

Fret not thy self because of evil doers, neither be thou envious against the
workers of iniquity. Fret not, etc. because of the man who brings wickekd
devices to pass, etc. Cease from anger, and forsake wrath: fret not thy self in
any wise to do evil, etc. But the meek shall inherit the earth, Psalm. 37. 1, 7,
8, 11.

The earth feared, etc. when God arose to judgment, to save all the meek of the
earth, Psalm 76. 8, 9.

It went ill with Moses for their sakes: because they provoked his spirit, so
that he spoke unadvisedly with his lips, Psalm. 106. 32, 33.

The Lord liftteh up the meek, Psalm. 147. 6.

Put away from thee a froward mouth: and perverse lips put far, Prove. 4. 24.

They who are of a froward heart, are an abomination to the Lord, Prove. 11. 20.

A fools wrath is presently known: but a wise man hides shame, Prove. 12. 16.

He who is soon angry, deals foolishly, etc. he who is slow to wrath is of
great: understanding: but he who is hasty (or, short) of spirit, exalts
folly, Prove. 14. 17, 29.

A soft answer turns away wrath: but grievous words stirs up anger, etc. a
wrathful man stirs up strife: but he who is slow to anger, appeaseth strife,
Prove. 15. 1. 18.

A froward man sows strife, etc. he who is slow to anger, is better than the
mighty: and he who rules his spirit, than he who takes a city, Prove. 16. 28,
32. Chap. 25. 28.

He who has a froward heart finds no good: and he who has a perverse
tongue, falls into mischief, Prove. 17. 20.

The discretion of a man deferreth anger: his glory to pass over a
transgression, etc. a man of great wrath shall suffer punishment; for if thou
deliver him, yet thou must do it again, Prove. 19. 11. 19.

It is an honor to a man to cease from strife: but every fool will be meddling,
Prove. 20. 3.

As coals to burning coals, and wood to fire: so is a contentious man to kindle
strife, Prove. 26. 21.

A stone is heavy, etc. but a fools wrath is heavier, etc. wrath is cruel, and
anger is outrageous: but who is able to stand before envy (or, jealousy)?
Prove. 27. 3, 4.

Wise men turn away wrath, etc. See thou a man who is hasty in his words (or,
matters), there is more hope of a fool than of him, etc. an angry man stirs
up strife, and a furious man abounds in transgression, Prove. 29. 8, 20, 22.

Better, etc. the patient in spirit, than the proud in spirit: be not hasty in
thy spirit to be angry, for anger rests in the bosom of fools, Eccl. 7. 8, 9.

The meek also shall increase (or, add to) their joy in the Lord, Isa. 29. 19.

Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth, etc. Blessed are the
peacemakers, for they shall be called the children of God, Mat. 5. 5, 9.

Learn of me, for I am meek and lowly of heart, and ye shall find rest, Mat.
11. 29.

Behold, thy King comes unto thee meek, etc. Mat. 21. 5.

In your patience possess ye your souls, Luke 21. 19.

Who will render unto every man according unto his deeds, to them who by
patient continuing in well doing, seek for glory, etc. eternal life, Romans 2. 7.

Tribulation works patience, and patience experience, and experience hope,
etc. Romans 5. 3, 4, 5.

If it be possible, as much as lies in you, live peaceable with all men:
Dearly beloved, avenge not your selves, but rather give place unto wrath: for
it is written, Vengance is mine, etc. Be not overcome of evil, Romans 12. 18, 19,
21.

Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace, Romans 14. 19.

Charity suffers long, and is kind; charity envieth not, etc. is not easily
provoked, etc. Romans 13. 4. 5.

The fruits of the flesh, etc. are wrath, strife, etc. but the fruits of the
spirit, is peace, long-suffering, gentleness, etc. meekness, temperance, etc.
Gal. 5. 20, 22, 23.

If any man be overtaken in a fault, ye who are spiritual, restore such a one
in the spirit of meekness; considering, etc. Gal. 6. 1.

Walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called, with all lowliness and
meekness, with long-suffering, forbearing: Be ye angry, and sin not; let not
the Sun go down upon your wrath, neither give place to the Devil, etc. let all
bitterness, and wrath, and anger, and clamor, and evil speaking, be put away
from you, with all malice, Ephesians. 4. 1, 2, 26, 27, 31.

Let your moderation be known unto all men: the Lord is at hand, Phil. 4. 5.

That ye walk worthy of the Lord, etc. strengthened with all might, according
unto his glorious power, unto all patience and long-suffering, Col. 1. 10, 11.

But now you also put off all these, anger, wrath, malice, etc. Put on
meekness, long-suffering, forbearing one another, Col. 3. 8, 12.

Be patient toward all men, 1 These. 5. 14.

But thou, O man of God, etc. follow after, etc. patience, meekness, 1 Timothy 6.
11. 2 Timothy 3. 10.

The servant of the Lord must not strive; but be gentle unto all men, etc.
patient (or, forbearing), in meekness instructing those who oppose themselves,
if God, etc. 2 Timothy 2. 24, 25.

That aged men be sober, grave, temperate, etc. in patience, Tit. 2. 2.

Put them in mind, etc. to be no brawler, gentle, showing all meekness unto all
men, Tit. 3. 1, 2.

Ye have need of patience, that after ye have done the will of God, ye might
receive the promise, Heb. 10. 36.

Follow peace with all men, Heb. 12. 14.

The trial of your faith works patience. But let patience have her perfect
work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing, etc. let every man
be, etc. slow to wrath: for the wrath of man works not the righteousness of
God, etc. receive with meekness the ingrafted word, James 1. 3, 4, 19, 20, 21.

Who is a wise man, etc? let him show out of a good conversation his works with
meekness of wisdom. But if ye have bitter envyings and strife in your heart,
etc. for where envy and strife is, there is confusion, etc. But the wisdom
which is from above, is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, and easy to be
entreated, etc. James 3. 13, 14, 16, 17.

Gird up the loins of your mind: be sober, and hope, etc. 1 Pet. 1. 13.

What glory is it, if when ye be buffeted for your faults, ye take it
patiently? but if when ye do well, and suffer for it, you take it patiently,
this is acceptable with God, 1 Pet. 2. 20.

Whose adorning, let it not be that outward, etc. but the hidden man of the
heart, in that which is not corruptible: the ornament of a meek and quiet
spirit, which is in the sight of God of great price, etc. He who will love
life, etc. let him seek peace, and ensue it, etc. Be always ready to give an
answer to every man who asks you a reason of the hope that is in you, with
meekness and fear, 1 Pet. 3. 3, 4, 10, 11, 15.

The end of all things is at hand, be ye therefore sober, 1 Pet. 4. 7.

Add, etc. to knowledge, temperance; and to temperance, patience, 2 Pet. 1. 6.

See more in Duties to brethren, Chap. 17.

In Duties toward all men, Chap. 19.

In Duties toward persecutors, Chap. 22.

In words, Chap. 16.

To take heed to our lips, that our words be not rash, but true, seasonable,
well ordered and savoury.
Ye shall not, etc. lie one to another, Levit. 19. 11.

How forcible are right words? But what does your arguing reprove? Job 6. 25.
26.

Ye are forgers of lies, etc. O that you would altogether hold your peace, and
it should be your wisdom, etc. Will you speak wickedly for God? and talk
deceitfully for him? Job 13. 4, 5, 7.

He who speaks flattery to his friends, even the eyes of his children shall
fail, Job 17. 5.

My lips shall not speak wickedness, nor my tongue utter deceit, Job 27. 4.

Now Elihu had waited till Job had spoken, because they were elder than he,
etc. He said, I am young, and ye very old; wherefore I was afraid, and durst
not show my opinion, Job 32. 4, 6.

I uttered that I understood not, things two wonderful for me, which I knew
not, etc. wherefore I abhor, etc. Job 42. 3, 6.

Thou shall destroy them who speak a lie, Psalm. 5. 6.

They speak vanity every one with his neighbor: with flattering lips, with a
double heart do they speak: the Lord will cut off all flattering lips, etc. who
have said, With our tongue will we speak, our lips are our own, who is Lord
over us? Psalm. 12. 2, 3, 4.

Lord, who shall abide in thy tabernacle, etc? he who speaks the truth in his
heart, he who backbiteth not with his tongue, Psalm. 15. 1, 2, 3.

I am purposed, that my mouth shall not transgress, Psalm. 17. 3.

What man is he who desires life, etc. Keep thy tongue from evil, and thy lips
from speaking guile, Psalm. 34. 12, 13.

The mouth of the righteous speaks wisdom, and his tongue talks of
judgment, Psalm. 37. 30.

I said, I will take heed to my ways, that I sin not with my tongue: I will
keep my mouth with a bridle, while the wicked is before me, Psalm. 39. 1.

Thou gave thy mouth to evil, and thy tongue framed deceit: thou sit and
speak against thy brother, etc. Psalm. 50. 19, 20.

The wicked, etc. go astray as soon as they are born, speaking lies, Psalm. 58.
3.

The mouth of them who speak lies, shall be stopped, Psalm. 63. 11.

My tongue also shall talk of thy righteousness all the day long, Psalm. 71. 24.

It went ill with Moses for their sakes: because they provoked his spirit, so
that he spoke unadvisedly with his lips, Psalm. 106. 32, 33.

I hate and abhor lying, Psalm. 119. 163.

Put away from thee a froward mouth: and perverse lips put far from thee, Prove.
4. 24.

These six things does the Lord hate, etc. a lying tongue, etc. a false
witness, speaking lies, Prove. 6. 16, 17, 19.

A prating fool shall fall: the mouth of a righteous man is a well of life,
etc. in the lips of him who has understanding, wisdom is found, etc. He who
hides hatred with lying lips, and he who utters a slander, is a fool: in the
multitude of words there wants not sin; but he who refraineth his lips is
wise. The tongue of the just is as choice silver, etc. The lips of the
righteous feed many, etc. the mouth of the just brings forth wisdom, etc. the
lips of the righteous knows what is acceptable, Prove. 10. 10, 11, 13, 18, 19,
20, 21, 31, 32.

He who speaks truth, shows forth righteousness, etc. lying lips are an
abomination to the Lord: but they who deal truly are his delight, Prove. 12. 17,
22.

He who keeps his mouth, keeps his life: but he who opens wide his lips,
shall have destruction, etc. a righteous man hates lying, Prove. 13. 3, 5.

A soft answer turns away wrath: but grievous words stir up anger: The tongue
of the wise uses knowledge aright; but the mouth of fools pours forth
foolishness, etc. A wholesome tongue is a tree of life: but perverseness therein
is a breach in the spirit, etc. The lips of the wise disperseth knowledge, etc.
A man has joy by the answer of his mouth, and a word spoken in due season, how
good it is! The heart of the righteous studieth to answer: but the mouth of the
wicked pours out evil things, Prove. 15. 1, 2, 4, 7, 23, 28.

Righteous lips are the delight of kings: and they love him who speaks right,
etc. The heart of the wise teaches his mouth, and adds learning unto his
lips. Pleasant words are as an honeycomb, sweet to the soul, Prove. 16. 13, 23,
24.

Excellent speech becomes not a fool: much less do lying lips a Prince, etc. He
who has a perverse tongue falls into mischief, etc. He who has knowledge,
spares his words, etc. Even a fool when he holds his peace, is counted wife:
He who shuts his lips is a man of understanding, Prove. 17. 7, 20, 27, 28.

A fools lips enter into contention, and his mouth calls for strokes, etc.
His mouth is his destruction, and his lips the snare of his soul, etc. The word
of a talebearer (or, whisperer) are as wounds, etc. He who answers a matter
before he hears, it is folly and shame unto him, etc. Death and life is in
the power of the tongue, etc. The rich man answers roughly, Prove. 18. 6, 7,
8, 13, 21, 23.

He who speaks lies shall perish, etc. shall not escape, Prove. 19. 5, 9.

Whosoever keeps his mouth and his tongue, keeps his soul from troubles, Prove.
21. 23.

A word fitly spoken, is like apples of gold in pictures of silver, Prove. 25.
11.

Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him:
answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit, Prove.
26. 4, 5.

Let another man praise thee, not thine own mouth: a stranger, not thine own
lips, Prove. 27. 2.

A fool utters all his mind, but a wise man keeps it in till afterward,
etc. See thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool
than of him, Prove. 29. 11, 20.

Be not rash with thy mouth: and let not thine heart be hasty to utter any
thing before God, etc. Let thy words be few, etc. for in many words also diverse
vanities: but fear thou God, Eccl. 5. 2, 3, 7.

The words of wise men are heard in quiet, Eccl. 9. 17.

The words of a wise man's mouth are gracious (or, grace), etc. A fool also is
full of words; a man cannot tell what shall be, Eccl. 10. 12, 14.

I hearkened and heard, they spoke not aright, etc. Jer. 8. 6.

They bent their tongue like their bow, for lies: but are not valiant for the
truth, etc. will not speak the truth; they have taught their tongue to speak
lies, etc. Their tongue is an arrow shot out, it speaks deceit; one speaks
peaceably to his neighbor with his mouth, in his heart he lays in wait, Jer.
9. 3, 5, 8.

The Lord has a controversy, etc. because there is no truth, etc. by swearing
and lying, etc. Hosea 4. 1, 2.

The prudent shall keep silence in that day: for it is an evil time, Amos 5. 13.

Keep the doors of thy mouth from her who lies in thy bosom, Micah 7. 5.

Speak ye every man truth to his neighbor, Zech. 8. 16.

How can ye being evil, speak good things? for out of the abundance of the
heart the mouth speaks. A good man out of the good treasure of the heart,
brings forth good things: and an evil man out of the evil treasure of his
heart brings forth evil things: But I say unto you, That every idle word
which men shall speak, they shall give an account thereof in the day of
judgment; for by thy words thou shall be justified, and by thy words thou shall
be condemned, Mat. 12. 34, 35, 36, 37.

Those things which proceed out of the mouth, comes forth from the heart, and
they defile the man, Mat. 15. 18.

And all wondered at the gracious words which proceeded out of his mouth; Luke
4. 22.

Peter (too rashly) said unto Christ, Thou shall never wash my feet, Joh. 13. 8.

Bless, and curse not, Romans 12. 14.

In the Church I had rather speak five words with my understanding, that I
might teach others also, than ten thousand words in an unknown tongue, etc. It
is a shame for a woman to speak in the Church, 1 Cor. 14. 19, 35.

Evil communication corrupt good manners, 1 Cor. 15. 33.

Wherefore putting away lying, speak every man truth with his neighbor, etc.
Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but that which is good
to the use of edifying (or, to edify profitable), that it may minister grace
unto the hearers: and grieve not the holy Spirit of God, etc. Let all
bitterness, etc. and clamor, and evil speaking, be put away, Ephesians. 4. 25, 29,
30, 31.

But fornication, etc. let it not be once named amongst you, as becomes
Saints; neither filthy nor foolish talking, nor jesting, which are not
convenient, Ephesians. 5. 3, 4.

But now also put off all these, etc. blasphemy, filthy communication out of
your mouth: lie not one to another, etc. Col. 3. 8, 9.

Let your speech be always with grace, seasoned with salt, that you may know
how ye ought to answer every man, Col. 4. 6.

Neither give heed to fables, etc. which minister questions rather than godly
edifying, 1 Timothy 1. 4.

They learn to be idle, etc. and not only idle, but tatlers also, and
busybodies, speaking things which they ought not, 1 Timothy 5. 13.

Doting about questions, and strifes of words, whereof comes envy, strife,
railing, etc. perverse disputings of men of corrupt minds, etc. 1 Timothy 6. 4, 5.

Charging them before the Lord, that they strive not about words to no profit,
to the subverting of the hearers, etc. Shun profane and vain bablings, for
they will increase unto more ungodliness; and their word will eat as does a
canker, etc. but foolish and unlearned questions avoid, knowing that they do
gender strifes, 2 Timothy 2. 14, 16, 17, 23.

In all things show thy self a pattern, etc. sound speech which cannot be
condemned; that he who is of the contrary party may be ashamed, Titus 2. 7, 8.

Speak evil of no man: to be no brawler, etc. Titus 3. 2.

Let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, etc. If any man among you seem
to be religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceives his own heart; this
man's religion is vain, James 1. 19, 26.

If any man offend not in word, the same is a perfect man, and able also to
bridle the whole body. Behold we put bits in horses mouths, etc. The ships
though great, etc. yet are they turned about with a small helm whithersoever
the governor lists: so the tongue is a little member, and boasts great
things, etc. And the tongue is a fire, a world of iniquity: so is the tongue
among our members, that it defiles the whole body, and sets on fire the
course of nature, and it is set on fire of hell. For every kind of beast, etc.
has been tamed of man; but the tongue can no man tame: an unruly evil full of
deadly poison: Therewith bless we God, even the Father: and therewith curse we
men, etc. out of the same mouth proceed blessings and cursings: My brethren,
these things ought not so to be, James 3. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.

Speak not evil one of another brethren: for whosoever speaks evil of his
brother, and judges his brother, speaks evil of the law, James 4. 11.

Wherefore laying aside all malice, etc. and evil speaking, 1 Pet. 2. 1.

Not rendering, etc. railing for railing; but contrariwise blessing, etc. He who
would love life, and see good days, let him refrain his tongue from evil, and
his lips that they speak no guile, 1 Pet. 3. 9, 10.

But these as natural bruit beasts, etc. speak evil of the things they
understand not, 2 Pet. 2. 12.

The Lord, etc. to convince all, etc. of all their hard speeches which ungodly,
etc. have spoken against me, Jude, verse 14. 15.

All liars shall have their part in the lake which burns, etc. and there
shall in no wise enter in, etc. whosoever works, etc. and makes a lie, Rev.
21. 8, 27.

Without are dogs, etc. and whatsoever loves and makes a lie, Rev. 22. 15.

To acknowledge and mourn for sin, depart from it, and watch against it, the
arguments: God complains of it, reasoning with sinners about it; threatenings
and judgments against sin and sinners.
1. What sin is.
By the Law is the knowledge of sin, Romans 3. 20. Romans 7. 7, 13.

Sin is the transgression of the Law, 1 John 3. 4.

All unrighteousness in sin, 1 John 5. 17.

2. Acknowledge sin unto God, both their own and others: and mourn for them.
And Moses returned unto the Lord and said, Oh this people have sinned a great
sin, and have made them gods of gold, etc. Exodus 32. 31.

And Aaron shall lay both of his hands upon the head of the live goat, and

4. Gods reasonings with, complainings of, and threatenings, and judgments

dreams nor by urim, nor by Prophets, etc. Then he goes to a familar spirit,
etc. Samuel said, Why have thou disquieted me, etc. Saul said, God is departed
from me, and answers me no more, etc. The Lord has rent the kingdom out of
thine hand: because thou obeyed not the voice of the Lord, nor executed his
fierce wrath upon Amalek, etc. therefore has the Lord done this thing unto
thee this day, etc. 1 Samuel 18. 6, 7, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19.

Uzzah put forth his hand unto the Ark of God, and took hold of it, etc. and
the anger of the Lord was kindled against Uzzah; and God smote him there for
his error (or, rashness), and there he dyed, etc. Michal David's wife despised
David for his dancing before the Ark, etc. therefore she had no child unto the
day of her death, etc. 2 Samuel 6. 16, 23.

David's sin in the matter of Uriahs wife, etc. displeased the Lord, 2 Samuel 11.
27.

And Nathan said unto David, etc. Thus says the Lord God of Israel, I anointed
thee king over Israel, etc. and if that had been too little, I would moreover
have given unto thee such and such things: Wherefore have thou despised the
commandment of the Lord, to do evil in his sight; that thou have killed Uriah,
etc. Now therefore the sword shall never depart from thy house, etc. Behold, I
will raise up evil against thee out of thine own house; and I will take thy
wives before thine eyes, and give unto thy neighbor, and he shall lie with thy
wife in the sight of this Sun, etc. the child also shall surely dye, etc. And
the child dyed, 2 Samuel 12. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 14, 18.

Then Amnon his son forces Tamar, sister of Absalom, etc. And Absalom kills
A^non, 2 Samuel 13. 11, 12, 13, 14, 28, 29.

Absalom conspired against David, and rebels, 2 Samuel 15.

Absalom went in unto his fathers concubines, in the sight of all Israel, 2 Samuel 16. 21, 22.

Absalom is slain himself, 2 Samuel 18. 14, 15.

There was a famine, etc. and David enquired of the Lord, and the Lord
answered, It is for Saul, and his bloody house; because he slew the Gibeonites,
etc. The children of Israel had sworn unto them, and Saul sought to slay them
in his zeal, etc. 2 Samuel 21. 1. Josh. 9. 15.

And the anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, etc. David said, Go
number the people, etc. So the Lord sent a pestilence upon Israel, etc. And
there dyed seventy thousand men, 2 Samuel 24. 1, 2, 15.

Adonijah put to death by Solomon's order: and Joab for his sin, killing of
Abner; and Amasa also put to death: and Shimei also put to death for his
cursing of David, 1 Kings 2. 24, 25, 28, 31, 32, 33, 34.

If you shall at all turn from following of me, you or your children; and will
not keep my commandments, etc. then will I cut off Israel out of the land which
I have given them; and this house which I have hallowed for my name, will I
cast out of my sight, and Israel shall be a proverb, and a byword, etc. 1
Kings 9. 6, 7, 8.

And the Lord was angry with Solomon, because his heart was turned from the
Lord God of Israel, who had appeared unto him twice, etc. Therefore the Lord
said unto Solomon, Forasmuch as this is done of thee, and thou have not kept my
covenant, etc. I will surely rend the kingdom from thee, and will give it to
thy servant, 1 Kings 11. 9, 10, 11.

It was charged me by the word of the Lord, saying, Eat no bread, etc. Thus

and have eaten bread, and drank water, etc. Thy carcass shall not come unto the
sepulcher of thy fathers, etc. A Lion met him by the way, and slew him, etc. It
is the man of God, 1 Kings 13. 8, 9, 21, 22, 24, 25, 26.

Tell Jeroboam, etc. Forasmuch as I have exalted thee from among the people,
and made thee prince, etc. yet thou have done evil above all that were before
thee, for thou have gone and made thee other gods, etc. Therefore behold, I
will bring evil upon the house of Jeroboam, and will cut off from Jeroboam him
who pisseth against the wall, etc. him who dies of Jeroboam in the city, shall
dogs eat; and him who dies in the field, shall the fowls of the air eat; for
the Lord has spoken it, 1 Kings 14. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.

Baasha smote all the house of Jeroboam, he left not to Jeroboam any that

Because of the sins of Jeroboam which he had sinned, and which he made Israel
sin, 1 Kings 15. 27, 29, 30.

The very like threatening did God send to Baasha for his sin, etc. and

12, 13.

God threatens, and sends a famine in Israel for the sins of Ahab, etc. 1 Kings

He killed Naboth and possessed his vineyard, etc. Thus says the Lord, Have

22. 38. 2 Kings 10. 33.

Ahaziah fell down, etc. He sent to enquire of the God of Ekron, etc. And the

So it was, that the children of Israel had sinned against the Lord their God,

ways, etc. notwithstanding they would not hear, but hardened their necks, etc.
Therefore the Lord was very angry with Israel, and removed them out of his

his sight, 2 Kings 17. 7, 8, 9, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19, 20.

Because Manasseh king of Judah has done these abominations, and has done
wickedly above all that the Amorites did, etc. and has made Judah also to sin,

upon Jeroboam and Judah, that whosoever hears of it, both his ears shall
tingle, etc. I will forsake the remnant of mine inheritance, and deliver them
into the hands of their enemies, etc. because they have done, etc. 2 Kings 21.

The Lord turned not from the fierceness of his wrath, wherewith his anger was
kindled against Judah, because of all the provocations that Manasseh had

26, 27.

God accordingly gives them up wholly to their enemies, 2 Kings 24. Chap. 25.

Uzziah the king, when he was strong, his heart was lifted up to his
destruction, etc. He went into the Temple of the Lord to burn incense; and when
the Priests withstood him, he was wrath; and while he was yet wrath with the

him; and Uzziah the King was a leper unto the day of his death, 2 Chr. 26. 16,
17, 18, 19, 20, 21.

Moreover, all the chief of the Priests and the people transgressed very much,
etc. And the Lord God of their fathers sent to them by his messengers, etc. but
they mocked the messengers of God, and despised his word, and misused his

36. 13, 14, 15, 16, 17.

They have chosen their own ways, and their soul delights in their

O Jerusalem, wash thine heart from wickedness that thou may be saved: how

How shall I pardon thee for this? thy children have forsaken me, and sworn by

and: to wait for Christ's second coming.

earth, etc. Job 19. 25.

I will speak of thy testimonies also before kings, and will not be ashamed,
etc. I am a companion of all them who fear thee, Psalm. 119. 46, 63. Psalm. 16.

The parenrs of the blind man durst not confess Christ, but answered, He is of
age, ask him: these words spoke his parents, because they feared the Jews; for
the Jews had agreed already, that if any man did confess that he was Christ,
that he should be put out of the Synagogue; therefore said his parents, he is
of age, ask him, etc. but the son confessed him, John 9. 19, 20, 21, 22, 23,
30, 31, 32, etc.

Nevertheless among the chief rulers also, many believed on him; but because of

See that ye walk circumspectly, not as fools, but as wise, Ephesians. 5. 15.

Beware of dogs, beware of evil workers: beware of the concision, Phil. 3. 2.

Beware, lest any man spoil you through philosophy and vain deceit, after the
tradition of men, etc. not after Christ, Col. 2. 8.

Continue in praying, and watch in the same, Col. 4. 2.

We are not of the night, nor of darkness; therefore let us not sleep as
others: but let us watch and be sober, for they who sleep, sleep in the night,
etc. 1 These. 5. 5, 6, 7.

Some shall depart from the faith, etc. some are already turned aside, etc.
have erred concerning the faith, 1 Timothy 4. 1. chapter 5. 15. chapter 6. 10, 21.

Take heed brethren, lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief, in
departing from the living God, etc. lest any of you be hardened through the
deceitfulness of sin, Heb. 3. 12, 13.

Let us therefore fear, lest a promise being left us of entering into rest, any
of you should seem to come short of it, etc. lest any man fall, etc. Heb. 4. 1,
11.

The end of all things is at hand: be ye therefore sober, and watch unto
prayer, 1 Pet. 4. 7.

Be sober, be vigilant, because your adversary the Devil, like a roaring Lion,
walks about, seeking whom he may devour, 1 Pet. 5. 8, 9.

Seeing ye know before, beware left ye also being led away with the error of
the wicked: fall from your own stedfastness, 2 Pet. 3. 17.

Look to your selves, that we lose not those things which we have gained, 2
John v. 8.

Be watchful, and strengthen the things which remain, etc. If thou shall not
watch, etc. Rev. 3. 2, 3.

Behold, I come as a thief: blessed is he who watches, and keeps his
garments, lest he walks naked, and they see his shame, Rev. 16. 15.

See the Saints aptness to fall into sin, Chap. 13.

See the Devil, and Deceivers ways to draw aside, Chap. 30.

CHAP. XVII. Of the Duties of Saints, Believers, Brethren in the Lord, each to
other, as such, and as standing in that relation one to another.
1st. To love one another; the kinds of it.
THou shall love thy neighbor as thy self: I am the Lord, Levit. 19. 18.

My goodness extends not unto thee: but to the saints who are in the earth, and
to the excellent in whom is all my delight, Psalm. 16. 2, 3.

I am a companion of all them who fear thee, etc. Psalm. 119. 63.

Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, then a stalled ox, where hatred is,
Prove. 15. 17.

Love is as strong as death, etc many waters cannot quench love, Cant. 8. 6, 7.

Thou shall love thy neighbor as thy self: on these two commandments hang all
the law and the Prophets, Matt. 22. 39, 40.

The love of many shall wax cold, Matt. 24. 12.

A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another, as I have loved
you, that ye also love one another: by this shall all men know that ye are my
disciples, if ye love one another, John 13. 34, 35.

This is my commandment, that ye love one another, as I have loved you, Joh.
15. 12, 13, 17.

We being many are one body in Christ, and every one members one of another,
etc. let love be without dissimulation, etc. be kindly affectioned one to
another, with brotherly love (or, in the love of the brethren) Romans 12. 5, 9,
10. 1 Cor. 12. 13, 25, 27.

Owe no man any thing, but to love one another: for he who loves another, has
fulfilled the law, etc. it is briefly comprehended in this saying, namely, Thou
shall love thy neighbor as thy self. Love works no ill to his neighbor,
Romans 13. 8, 9, 10. Gal. 5. 13, 14.

Though I speak with the tongue of men or angels, etc. have the gift of
prophecy, etc. have all faith, etc. bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and
though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profits me
nothing: charity suffers long, etc. charity never fails, etc. 1 Cor. 13. 1,
2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 13.

Follow after charity, 1 Cor. 14. 1.

Let all your things be done with charity, 1 Cor. 16. 14.

There is neither Jew nor Greek, etc. for ye are all one in Christ Jesus, Gal.
3. 28.

The sruit of the spirit is love, etc. Gal. 5. 22.

Walk in love, as Christ also has loved us, etc. Ephesians. 5. 2.

I pray that your love may abound more and more in knowledge, etc. Phil. 1. 9.

Having the same love, etc. look not every man on his own things, but every man
also on the things of others. Phil. 2. 2, 4.

We give thanks, etc. since we heard, etc. of the love which ye have unto all
saints, Col. 1. 3, 4. Ephesians. 1. 15.

That their hearts might be comforted, being knit together in love, Col. 2. 1,
2.

Above all these things, put on charity, which is the bond of perfectness, Col.
3. 14.

The Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another, 1 These.
3. 12.

As touching brotherly love, ye need not that I write unto you: for ye your
selves are taught of God to love one another, etc. that ye increase more, 1
These. 4. 9, 10.

We are bound to thank God, etc. because that your faith grows exceedingly,
and the charity of every one of you all toward each other abounds, 2 These.
1. 3.

Now the end of the commandment is, love out of a pure heart, 1 Timothy 1. 5.

Follow, etc. love, 2 Timothy 2. 22.

I thank my God, etc. hearing of thy love, etc. toward all saints, Philem. v.
4, 5.

God is not unrighteous to forget your work, and labor of love which ye have
showed toward his name, in that ye have ministered to the saints, and do, Heb.
6. 10.

Let brotherly love continue, Heb 13. 1.

If ye fulfill the royal law according to the scripture, thou shall love thy
neighbor as thy self, ye do well, James 2. 8.

If ye have bitter envying and strife in your hearts, glory not, etc. this
wisdom descends not from above, etc. James 3. 14, 15, 16.

Seeing ye have purified your souls in obeying the truth through the spirit,
unto unseigned love of the brethren, see that ye love one another with a pure
heart servently, 1 Pet. 1. 22.

Love the brotherhood, 1 Pet. 2. 17.

Finally, etc. love as brethren, (or, loving to brethren), 1 Pet. 3. 8.

And above all things, have fervent charity among your selves, 1 Pet. 4. 8.

Add, etc. to brotherly kindness, and to brotherly kindness, charity, 2 Pet. 1.
7.

He who says, he is in the light, and hates his brother, is in darkness even
until now: he who loves his brother, abides in the light, 1 John 2. 9, 10, 11.

Is not of God, neither he who loves not his brother: for this is the message
that ye heard from the beginning, that we should love one another, etc. We know
that we are passed from death to life, because we love the brethren, etc. we
ought to lay down our lives for the brethren; let us not love in word, neither
in tongue, but in deed and in truth, 1 John 3. 10, 11, 12, 14, 16, 18, 19.

Let us love one another: for love is of God, and every one who loves, is born
of God, and knows God: he who loves not, knows not God, for God is love,
etc. if God so loved us, we ought also to love one another, etc. if any man say
he loves God, and hates his brother, he is a liar, etc. this commandment have
we from him, that he who loves God, love his brother also, 1 John 4. 7, 8, 11,
12, 20, 21. 2 Epist. Joh. v. 5.

2dly, From love, to sympathize with each other in pity and compassion, help
and comfort one another, and bear one another burden: have mutual care.
The children of Israel (when they had in battle cut off the Benjamites, they
bemoan them) lift up their voices and wept sore: and said, O Lord God of
Israel, Why is this come to pass in Israel, that their should be to day one
tribe lacking in Israel, etc? and it repented them for Benjamin their brother:
and said, There is one tribe cut off from Israel this day: How shall we do for
wives for them, etc? Judges 21. 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16.

With the merciful thou will show thy self merciful, 2 Samuel 22. 26. Psalm. 18.
25.

Thus says the Lord of Host, etc. show mercy and compassion every man to his
brother, and oppress not the widow, Zech. 7. 9, 10.

Blessed are the merciful, for they shall obtain mercy, Mat. 5. 7.

Come ye blessed, etc. I was hungry, and ye gave me meat; I was thirsty, and ye
gave me drink; I was a stranger, and ye took me in; naked, and ye clothed me; I
was sick, and ye visited me; I was in prison, and ye came unto me, etc. Verily
I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my
brethren, ye have done it unto me, Mat. 25. 34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40.

In the parable of the man who fell among the thieves: one looked upon the
wounded man, and another did so: but a certain Samaritan saw him, had
compassion on him, bound up his wounds, etc. He who showed mercy was his
neighbor: Go and do thou likewise, Luke 10. 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37.

I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not: and when thou art converted,
strengthen thy brethren, Luke 22. 32.

Rejoice with them who do rejoice, and weep with them who weep: Be of the same
mind one toward another, Romans 12. 15, 16.

We then who are strong, ought to bear with the infirmities of the weak, and
not to please our selves: Let every one of us please his neighbor, for his
good to edification, Romans 15. 1, 2. 1 Cor. 8. 1.

To the weak, became I as weak, that I might gain the weak, etc. 1 Cor. 9. 22.

Let no man seek his own, but every man another wealth, etc. As I please all
men, 1 Cor. 10. 24, 33.

By one spirit are we all baptized into one body, etc. that the members should
have the same care one of another: and whether one member suffer, all the
members suffer with it: or one member be honored, all the members rejoice with
it. Now are ye the body of Christ, and members in particular, 1 Cor. 12. 12,
13, 18, 25, 26, 27.

Charity, etc. seeks not her own, 1 Cor. 13. 4, 5.

Blessed be God, etc. the Father of mercies, and the God of all comfort, who
comfort us, etc. that we may be able to comfort them who are in any trouble,
by the comfort wherewith we our selves are comforted of God, 2 Cor. 1. 3, 4.

Who is weak, and I am not weak? who is offended, and I burn not? 2 Cor. 11. 29.

Bear ye one another burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ, Gal. 6. 1, 2.

We are members one of another, etc. Be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted,
Ephesians. 4. 25, 32.

Put on therefore (as the elect of God, holy and beloved) bowels of mercy,
kindness, etc. Col. 3. 12.

Comfort the feeble minded, support the weak, 1 These. 5. 14.

Ye endured a great fight of afflictions, etc. by reproaches and afflictions,
and partly whilst ye became companions of them who were so used: for ye had
compassion on me in my bonds, Heb. 10. 32, 33, 34.

Be not forgetful to entertain strangers, for thereby some have entertained
Angels, etc. Remember them who are in bonds, as bound with them, and them who
suffer adversity, as being your selves also in the body, Heb. 13. 2, 3.

Pure religion, etc. is this, to visit the fatherless and widows in their
afflictions, James 1. 27.

The Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy, James 5. 11.

Be ye all of one mind, having compassion one of another, etc. Be pitiful, etc.
1 Pet. 3. 8.

Whosoever has this worlds goods, and sees his brother has need, and shuts up
his bowels of compassion from him, how dwells the love of God in him? 1 John
3. 17.

He shall have judgment without mercy who has showed no mercy: and mercy
rejoices against judgment, James 2. 13.

See this duty in time of affliction, or persecution, Chap. 22.

3dly, To honor and respect each other: and be kind and affectionate.
Lord, who shall abide in thy tabernacle, etc? he in whose eyes a vile person
is contemned: But he honors them who fear the Lord, Psalm. 15. 1, 4.

My goodness extends not unto thee, but to the Saints who are in the earth,
and to the excellent in whom is all my delight, Psalm. 16. 2, 3.

When Christ had washed his Disciples feet; he said, If I then your Lord and
Master have washed your feet, ye also ought to wash one another feet, Joh. 13.
12, 13, 14, 15.

Be kindly affectionate one to another, with brotherly love: in honor
preferring one another, Romans 12. 10. Ephesians. 4. 32. 2 Pet. 1. 7.

Charity suffers long, and is kind, 1 Cor. 13. 4.

As we have opportunity let us do good unto all men: especially to them who are
of the household of faith, Gal. 6. 10.

Submitting your selves one to another in the fear of God, Ephesians. 5. 21.

Salute every Saint in Christ Jesus, etc. all the Saints salute you, Phil. 4.
21, 22.

Have not the faith of our Lord Jesus, etc. with respect of persons: For, etc.
James 2. 1.

Use hospitality one to another without grudgings, 1 Pet. 4. 9.

We ought to lay down our lives for the brethren, 1 John 3. 16.

Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory: but in lowliness of mind let
each esteem other better than themselves, Phil. 2. 3.

4dly, Not rashly, easily and unadvisedly take up a prejudice against any;
believe reports, take offense or be angry; but tenderly to forgive, cover
faults, restore such as have offended, in meekness, love and privacy.
Noah was uncovered: Ham saw his fathers nakedness, and told his two brethren
without, and Shem and Japhet took a garment and laid it upon their shoulders,
and went backward, and covered the nakedness of their father, etc. and they saw
not their fathers nakedness, etc. Genesis 9. 21, 22, 23, 24, 25.

When Joseph had told his dream, his brethren envied him: but his father
observed the saying, Genesis 37. 8, 9, 10, 11.

Thou shall not raise (or, receive) a false report, Exodus 23. 1.

When the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of
Manasseh had built an Altar to a good end; the rest of their brethren heard of
it, and presently concludes it to be a turning away from the Lord; and they
resolve rashly to go to war against them, Joshua 22. 10, 11, 12, 16, 17, 18,
etc.

When Absalom designed his rebellion, there went two hundred men out of
Jerusalem with him, and they went in their simplicity, and they knew not any
thing, 2 Samuel 15. 10, 11.

Lord, who shall abide in thy tabernacle, etc? he who backbiteth not, etc. nor
takes up (or, receives, or endures) a reproach against his neighbor, Psalm.
15. 1, 3.

The Lord is merciful, etc. slow to anger, Psalm. 103. 8.

Hatred stirs up strife: but love covers all sins, etc. He who utters a
slander is a fool, Prove. 10. 12, 18.

The simple believes every word: but the prudent man looks well to his
goings, etc. He who is soon angry, deals foolishly, Prove. 14. 15, 17.

He who covers a transgression, seeks love (or, procures love), Prove. 17.
9.

The discretion of a man deferreth his anger: and it is his glory to pass over
a transgression, Prove. 19. 11.

All who watch for iniquity are cut off: Who make a man an offender for a word,
Isa. 29. 21, 22.

Whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause, shall be in danger of the
judgment, Mat. 5. 22.

If ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive
you: But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, etc. Mat. 6. 14, 15.

Judge not, that ye be not judged, etc. Why beholdest thou the mote that is in
thy brothers eye, but considerest not the beam which is in thine own eye? or
how w^t thou say to thy brother, let me pull out, etc? Mat. 7. 1, 3, 4.

If thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between
him and thee al^ne: if he shall hear thee, thou have gained thy brother, etc.
Peter said, Lord, h^w ost shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him?
till s^ven times? Jesus said, unto him, I say not unto thee, until seven times,
but ^ntil seventy times-seven, etc. I forgave thee all that debt, etc.
Should thou not also have had compassion on thy f^llow-servant, even as I
had pity on thee, etc. and his Lord was wrath, etc. So likewise shall my
heavenly Father do also unto you, if ye from your hearts forgive not every one
his brother their tr^spasses, Mat. 18. 15, 21, 22, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33,
34, 35.

If thy brother trespass against thee, rebuke him; and if he repent, forgive
him: If he trespass against thee seven times a day, etc. thou shall forgive
him, Luke 17. 3, 4.

Judge not according to the appearance, but judge righteous judgment, Joh. 7. 24.

The believers of the circumcision rashly judged of Peter, and contended with
him for eating with the Gentiles: But when Peter gave them an account of the
cause, they held their peace, etc. Acts 11. 1, 2, 3, 4, 18.

Love works no ill to his neighbor, Romans 13. 10.

But with me it is a very small thing that I should he judged of you, or of
man's judgment (or, day), etc. Judge nothing before the time, until the Lord
come; who will both bring to light the hidden things of darkness, etc. 1 Cor.
4. 3, 4, 5.

Charity suffers long, etc. seeks not her own, is not easily provoked,
thinks no evil, etc. bears all things, believes all things, hops all
things, endures all things, 1 Cor. 13. 4, 5, 7.

In malice be ye children, 1 Cor. 14. 20.

The fruit of the spirit is, etc. long-suffering, gentleness, etc. meekness,
Gal. 5. 22, 23.

Brethren, if (or, although) a man be overtaken in a fault, ye who are
spiritual restore such a one in the spirit of meekness: considering thy self,
lest thou also be tempted: Bear ye one another burdens, and so fulfill the law
of Christ, Gal. 6. 1, 2.

Walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are called, with all lowliness and
meekness, with long-fuffering, forbearing one another in love, etc. Be
tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake has
forgiven you, Ephesians. 4. 1, 2, 32.

But now you also put off all these, anger, wrath, malice, etc. Put on
therefore, as the elect of God, etc. bowels of mercies, etc. meekness,
long-suffering, forbearing one another, and forgiving one another. If any man
have a complaint (or, quarrel) against any, even as Christ forgave you, so also
do ye, Col. 3. 8, 12, 13.

Let every man be, etc. slow to wrath: for the wrath of man works not the
righteousness of God, James 1. 19, 20.

Speak not evil one of another, brethren, for he who speaks evil of his
brother speaks evil of the Law, etc. Who art thou who judge another? James
4. 11, 12.

Above all things have fervent charity among your selves: for Charity shall
(or, will) cover the multitude of sins, 1 Pet. 4. 8.

5lthy, To live peaceably among themselves: avoid whispering, tale-bearing, and
whatsoever tends to provoke, divide, or disturb the peace among them.
Abram said unto Lot, Let there be no strife I pray thee between me and thee,
etc. for we be brethren, etc. If thou will take the left hand, then I will go
to the right; or if thou to the right hand, then will I go to the left, Genesis
13. 8, 9.

Thou shall not raise (or, receive) a false Prophet, Exodus 23. 1.

Lord, who shall abide in thy tabernacle, etc? he who backbiteth not with his
tongue, etc. nor takes up a reproach against his neighbor, Psalm. 15. 1, 3.

Seek peace and pursue it, Psalm. 34. 14.

It was not an enemy who reproached me, then could I have born it; but thou, a
man, mine equal, etc. We walked unto the house of God in company, Psalm. 55. 12,
13, 14.

Whosoever privily slandereth his neighbor, him will I cut off, Psalm. 101. 5.

I am for peace, etc. they for war, Psalm. 120. 7.

These things does the Lord hate, etc. him who sows discord among brethren,
Prove. 6. 16, 19.

A talebearer reveals secrets: but he who is of a faithful spirit concealeth
the matter, Prove. 11. 13.

Only by pride comes contention, Prove. 13. 10.

A whisperer separateth chief friends, Prove. 16. 28.

He who repeateth the matter, separateth friends, etc. the beginning of strife,
is as when one lets out water: therefore leave off contention before it be
meddled with, Prove. 17. 9, 14.

The words of a talebearer are as wounds, Prove. 18. 8.

It is an honor for a man to cease from strife, etc. He who goes about as a
talebearer, reveals secrets: therefore meddle not with him who flattereth,
Prove. 20. 3, 19.

Where there is no talebearer, the strife cease, Prove. 26. 20.

Can two walk together, except they be agreed? Amos 3. 3.

Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called the children of God,
Matthew. 5. 9.

Every kingdom divided against it self, is brought to desolation, Matthew. 12. 25.

If thy brother shall trespass, etc. go and tell him his fault between thee and
him alone, Matthew. 18. 15.

One is your Master, Christ, and all ye are brethren, Matthew. 23. 8.

Have peace one with another, Mark 9. 50.

If it be possible, as much as lies in you, live peaceably with all men, Romans
12. 18.

Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace, and things
wherewith one may edify another, Romans 14. 19.

Ye are yet carnal: for whereas there is among you envyings, and strifes, and
divisions (or, factions), are ye not carnal, and walk as men? for while one
says, I am of Paul, etc. are ye not carnal? 1 Cor. 3. 3, 4.

Is it so, that there is not a wise man among you? no, not one who shall be
able to judge between his brethren? but brother goes to law with brother, etc.
now therefore there is utterly a fault among you, because ye go to law, etc. 1
Cor. 6. 5, 6, 7.

Charity envieth not, 1 Cor. 13. 4.

For I fear, etc. lest there be debates, envyings, wraths, strifes,
backbitings, whisperings, etc. 2 Cor. 12. 20.

Brethren, etc. live in peace, and the God of love and peace shall be with you,
2 Cor. 13. 11.

If ye bite and devour one another, take heed ye be not consumed one of
another, etc. The fruit of the Spirit is, etc. peace, long-suffering,
gentleness, etc. Let us not be desirous of vainglory, provoking one another,
envying one another, Gal. 5. 15, 22, 26.

Endeavoring to keep the unity of the spirit in the bond of peace: one body,
etc. Let all bitterness, and wrath, and anger, and clamor, etc. be put away
from you, Ephesians. 4. 3, 4, 5, 6, 31.

Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory, etc. Phil. 2. 3.

That ye study to be quiet, and do your own business, etc. 1 These. 4. 11.

Be at peace among your selves, 1 These. 5. 13.

They learn to be idle, wandering about from house to house; and not only idle,
but talkers also, and busybodies: speaking things which they ought not, (...)
Tim. 5. 13.

Doting about questions and strifes of words: whereof comes envy, strife,
railing, etc. 1 Timothy 6. 4, 20.

Follow peace with them who call on the Lord, etc. but foolish and unlearned
questions avoid, knowing that they do gender strifes, 2 Timothy 2. 22, 23.

The aged women, etc. that they be not false-accusers (or, make-bates), Titus
2. 3.

Avoid foolish questions, etc. and contentions, and strivings about the Law:
for they, etc. Titus 3. 9.

Follow peace with all men, Heb. 12. 14.

If ye have bitter envyings and strife in your hearts: glory not, etc. This
wisdom is not from above, etc. for where envying and strife is, there is
confusion and every evil work: But the wisdom which is from above, is, etc.
peaceable, gentle, and easy to be entreated, etc. And the fruits of
righteousness is sown in peace of them who make peace, James 3. 14, 15, 16, 17,
18.

Whence comes wars and fightings among you? come they not hence, even of your
lusts, etc? speak not evil one of another, brethren, James 4. 1, 11.

Wherefore laying aside all malice, etc. and envyings, and evil speakings, 1
Pet. 2. 1.

Whose adoning, let it not be that outward, etc. but the hidden man, etc. of a
meek and quiet spirit, which is in the sight of God of great price, etc. not
rendering evil for evil, or railings: He who will love life, and see good days,
etc. let him seek peace and ensue it, 1 Pet. 3. 3, 4, 9, 10, 11.

6thly, To rebuke, reprove, exhort, admonish, and warn each other for, and
about sin, and their duty. And to take such rebukes, etc. well and kindly from
each other.
1st To rebuke, etc.
Thou shall not hate thy brother in thine heart: Thou shall in any wise rebuke
thy neighbor, and not suffer sin upon him (or, that thou bear not sin for
him), Lev. 19. 17.

Debate thy cause with thy neighbor, and discover not a secret to another,
etc. As an ear-ring of gold, etc. so is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear,
Prove. 25. 9, 12.

Open rebuke is better than secret love, Prove. 27. 5.

He who rebukes a man, afterward shall find more favor than he who
flattereth with the tongue, Prove. 28. 23.

If thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between
him and thee alone, etc. If he will not hear thee, then take one or two more,
etc. Matthew. 18. 15, 16, 17. Luke 17. 3, 4.

Ye also are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge: able to admonish one
another, Romans 15. 4.

Paul rebuked Peter for not walking uprightly, Gal. 2: 11, 12, 13, 14.

Let the word of Christ dwell in you richly, etc. teaching and admonishing one
another, Col. 3. 16.

Comfort (or, exhort) your selves together, and edify one another, even as
also ye do, etc. Warn them who are unruly (or disorderly), comfort the
feeble-minded, 1 These. 5. 11, 14.

If any man obey not, etc. have no company with him, etc. but admonish him as a
brother, 2 These. 3. 14, 15.

Rebuke not an Elder, but entreat him as a father, and the younger men as
brethren: the elder women as mothers, the younger as sisters, etc. Them that
sin rebuke before all, that others also may fear, 1 Timothy 5. 1, 2, 20.

Exhort one another daily, etc. lest any of you be hardened through the
decitsulness of sin, Heb. 3. 12, 13.

Let us consider one another, to provoke unto love and good works: not
forsaking the assemblings of your selves, etc. but exhorting one another, Heb.
10. 24, 25.

Brethren, if any one of you do err from the truth, and one convert him, let
him know that he, etc. shall save a soul from death, and shall hide, etc. James
5. 19, 20.

Of some have compassion, making a difference; and others save with fear,
pulling them out of the fire: hating even the garment spotted by the flesh,
Jude, verse 20. 22, 23.

See Discipline. Chap. 27.

To take rebuke, admonition, etc. well from each other.
When David had rashly resolved to cut off all Nabals family: and Abigail had
met him, and humbly and wisely admonished him: David accepts of the advice, and
says, Blessed be the Lord God of Israel who sent thee this day to meet me: and
blessed be thy advice, and blessed be thou who have kept me this day from
shedding of blood, etc. I have hearkened to thy voice, 1 Samuel 25. 22, 23, 24,
25, to the 35.

When Nathan had told David his sin in the matter of Uriah: David said, I have
sinned against the Lord, 2 Samuel 12. 7, 13.

When Joab had told the King of his error in mourning so for Absalom, as to
discourage his subjects who had fought for him; David hearkened and arose, and
sat in the gate, as Joab advised, 2 Samuel 19. 5, 6, 7, 8.

Let the righteous smite me, it shall be a kindness; and let him reprove me, it
shall be as excellent oil, which shall not break my head, Psalm. 141. 5.

A wise man will hear, and will increase learning, Prove. 1. 5.

Reprove not a scorner, lest he hate thee; rebuke a wise man, and he will love
thee: give instruction to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser, etc. Prove. 9.
8, 9.

He is in the way of life who keeps instruction: but he who refuses reproof,
erreth (or, causes to err), Prove. 10. 17.

Whosoever loves instruction, loves knowledge: but he who hates reproof, is
brutish, etc. he who hearkneth unto counsel, is wise, Prove. 12. 1, 15.

A wise son hears his fathers instruction: but a scorner hears not rebuke,
etc. Poverty and shame to him who refuses instruction: but he who regards
reproof shall be honored, Prove. 13. 1, 18.

A fool despises his fathers instruction: but he who regards reproof is
prudent, etc. He who hates reproof shall die, etc. A scorner loves not one
who reproves, etc. The ear which hears reproof of life, abides among the
wise: He who refuses instruction, despises his own soul, etc. Prove. 15. 5,
10, 12, 31, 32.

A reproof enters more into a wise man, than an hundred stripes into a fool,
Prove. 17. 10.

As an ear-ring of gold, etc. so is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear, Prove.
25. 12.

He who being often reproved, hardneth his neck, shall suddenly be destroyed,
and that without remedy, etc. The rod and reproof gives wisdom, Prove. 29. 1, 15.

Am I therefore become your enemy, because I tell you the truth? Gal. 4. 16.

Submit your selves one to another in the fear of God, Ephesians. 5. 21.

Ye younger submit your selves unto the elder; yea, all of you be subject one
to another: and be clothed with humility, 1 Pet. 5. 5.

7thly, To confess sin to, and pray each for other.
When a man or woman shall commit any sin, that men commit, to do a trespass
against the Lord, etc. then they shall confess their sin which they have done:
and he shall recompense his trespass, etc. and give it unto him against whom he
has trespassed, Numb. 5. 6, 7.

And many who believed, came and confessed, and showed their deeds, etc. Acts
19. 18, 19.

Paul confesses, that beyond measure he persecuted the Church of God, and
wasted it, etc. Gal. 1. 13. 1 Timothy 1. 12, 13.

Confess your fault one to another, and pray one for another, that ye may be
healed, Jam. 5. 16.

If a man see his brother sin a sin not unto death; he shall ask, and he shall
give him life for them who sin not unto death, 1 John 5. 16.

8thly, To be of one mind.
Behold, how good, and how pleasant is it for brethren to dwell together in
Unity! like the precious ointment upon the head, etc. Psalm. 133. 1, 2.

Christ prays that they may be kept, that they may be one as we are, etc. Joh.
19. 11, 12.

And the multitude of them who believed were of one heart, and of one soul,
etc. Acts 4. 32.

We being many, are one body in Christ; and every one members one of another,
etc. Be of the same mind one toward another, Romans 12. 5, 16.

Now the God, etc. grant you to be like-minded one toward another according to
Christ Jesus, that ye may with one mind and one mouth glorify God, even the
father, Romans 15. 5, 6.

I beseech you brethren, etc. that ye all speak the same things: and that there
be no division, but that ye be perfectly joined together in the same mind, and
in the same judgment, 1 Cor. 1. 10, 12.

Whereas there is among you, etc. divisions: Are ye not carnal, etc? One faith,
I am of Paul, etc. 1 Cor. 3. 3, 4.

When ye come together in the Church, I hear there be divisions among you, etc.
1 Cor. 11. 18, 23.

Finally brethren, etc. be of one mind, 2 Cor. 13. 11.

Endeavoring to keep the unity of the spirit in the bond of peace, etc. one
body, and one spirit, Ephesians. 4. 3, 4, 5.

That ye stand fast in one spirit, with one mind, striving together for the
faith, Phil. 1. 27.

If therefore there be any consolation in Christ, etc. fulfill ye my joy, that
ye be like-minded, etc. being of one accord, of one mind: let nothing be done
through strife or vainglory, etc. Phil. 2. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

Whereto we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule, let us mind
the same thing, Phil. 3. 16.

I beseech Euodias, etc. that they be of the same mind in the Lord, Phil. 4. 2.

Finally, be all of one mind, 1 Pet. 3. 8.

9thly, To walk wisely and charitably one toward another: and in things
indifferent to have respect to the meek; to avoid offenoes.
The Pharisees would have accused the disciples for plucking corn, and Christ
for healing a withered hand on the Sabbath day, till he said unto them, Which
of you having one sheep, etc. fall into a pit on the Sabbath day, will he not
lay hold on it, and lift it out, etc? it is lawful to do well on the Sabbath
day, Matthew. 12. 1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 12. Luke 6. 1, 2, etc.

Whosoever shall offend one of these little ones who believe in me, it were
better that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in
the midst of the sea. Woe unto the world because of offenses: for it must needs
be that offenses come, but woe to that man by whom the offense comes, Mat. 18,
6, 7. Luke 17. 1, 2.

His disciples say unto him, If the case of the man be so with his wife, it is
not good to marry: But he said unto them, All men cannot receive this saying,
save they to whom it is given: for there are foam Eunuchs which were so born,
etc. and there are some Eunuchs who have made themselves, etc. He who is able
to receive it, let him, Matthew. 19. 10, 11, 12.

Jesus said, I have yet many things to say unto you, but ye cannot bear them
now: howbeit when he, the spirit of truth is come, he will guide, John 16. 12,
13.

Him who is weak receive, but not with doubtful disputations (or, not to judge
his doubtful thoughts): for one believes that he may eat all things; another
who is weak eats herbs: let not him who eats, despise him who eats not;
and let not him who eats not, judge him who eats; for God has received him,
etc. One man esteems one day above another: another esteems every day
alike; let every man be fully persuaded in his own mind; he who observes a
day, observes it to the Lord, etc. Why do thou judge thy brother? why do
thou set at naught thy brother, etc? Let us not therefore judge one another any
more, but judge this rather, that no man put a stumbling block, or an occasion
to fall, in his brothers way. I know, etc. that there is nothing unclean of it
self; but to him who esteems any thing to be unclean, to him it is unclean.
And if thy brother be grieved with thy meat, now walk thou not charitably,
etc. Let us therefore follow after things which make for peace, etc. All things
indeed are pure, but it is evil for that man who eats with offense; it is
good neither to eat flesh, etc. whereby thy brother stumbleth, or is offended,
or made weak, etc. he who doubts is damned if he eat, etc. for whatsoever is
not of faith, is sin, Romans 14. 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 10, 13, 14, 15, 19, 20, 21, 23.

We then who are strong, ought to bear with the infirmities of the weak, and
not to please our selves: let every one of us please his neighbor for his good
to edification, Romans 15. 1, 2, 3.

I have fed you with milk, and not with meat: for hitherto ye were not able to
^ear it, neither yet now are ye able to bear it, 1 Cor. 3. 1, 2.

All things are lawful unto me, but all things are not expedient (or,
profitable): all things are lawful for me, but I will not be brought under the
power of any, etc. 1 Cor. 6. 12. chap. 10. 23.

I would that all men were even as I my self: but every man has his proper
gift of God; one after this manner, etc. Is any man called being circumcised?
let him not become uncircumcised; and is any called in uncircumcision? let him
not be circumcised; Circumcision is nothing, etc. 1 Cor. 7. 7, 18, 19.

We know that an Idol is nothing in the world, etc. howbeit, there is not in
every man that knowledge: for some with conscience of the Idol unto this hour,
eat it as a thing offered to Idols, and their conscience being weak, is
defiled. But meat commends us not to God, etc. Take heed lest by any means
this liberty of yours become a stumbling block to them who are weak: for if any
man see thee who have knowledge sit at meat in the Idols temple, shall not the
conscience of him which is weak, be emboldned to eat those things which are
offered to Idols, and through thy knowledge shall thy weak brother perish for
whom Christ died? but when ye sin so against the weak brethren, and wound their
weak conscience, ye sin against Christ; wherefore, if meat make my brother to
offend, I will eat no flesh while the world stands, lest I make my brother to
offend, 1 Cor. 8. 4, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13.

For though I be free from all men, yet have I made my self a servant unto all,
that I might gain the more: and unto the Jews I became as a Jew, that I might
gain the Jew, etc. To the weak became I as weak, etc. I am made all things unto
all men, that I might by all means save some, etc. 1 Cor. 9. 19, 20, 21, 22.

All things are lawful for me, but all things are not expedient, etc. all
things edify not: let no man seek his own, but every man another wealth:
whatsoever is sold in the shambles, that eat, asking no question for conscience
sake, for the earth is the Lords, etc. If any of them who believe not, bid you,
and ye be disposed to go, whatsoever is set before you, eat, asking no question
for conscience sake. But if any man say unto thee, this is offered in sacrifice
unto Idols: eat not for his sake who showed it, and for conscience sake, etc.
conscience, I say; not thine own, but of the others, etc. Give none offense,
neither to the Jews, nor to the Gentiles, nor to the Church of God; even as I
please all men in all things, not seeking mine own profit, but the profit of
many that they may be saved, 1 Cor. 10. 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 31, 32, 33.
chap. 11. 1.

Charity seeks not her own, 1 Cor. 13. 4, 5.

Let all your things be done with charity, 1 Cor. 16. 14.

Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of
others: let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus, Phil. 2. 4, 5.

Let us therefore as many as be perfect, be thus minded: and if in any thing ye
be otherwise-minded, God shall reveal even this unto you. Nevertheless,
whereunto we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule, let us mind
the same thing, Phil. 3. 15, 16.

Let no man therefore judge you, in meat or in drink (or, in eating or in
drinking) or in respect of an holy day, or of the new moon, or of the Sabbath,
which are a shadow of things to come: but the body is of Christ, Col. 2. 16, 17.

We exhort you brethren, etc. comfort the feeble minded, support the weak, be
patient toward all men, 1 These. 5. 14.

Neither give heed to fables, etc. which minister questions rather than godly
edifying, which is in faith: now the end of the commandment is charity, etc. 1 Timothy 1. 4, 5.

Some shall depart from the faith, etc. forbidding to marry, and commanding to
abstain from meats, which God has created to be received, etc. 1 Timothy 4. 3, 4,
5.

Unto the pure all things are pure, Tit. 1. 15.

When Paul was writing many things concerning Christ, he said, Of whom we have
many things to say, and hard to be uttered, seeing ye are dull of hearing, etc.
ye are become such as have need of milk and not of strong meat, etc. strong
meat belongs unto them who are of full age, Heb. 5. 10, 11, 12, 13, 14.

It is a good thing that the heart be established with grace, not with meats
which have not profited them who have been occupied therein, Heb. 13. 9.

I will put upon you no other burden; but that which ye have already, hold fast
till I come, Rev. 2. 24, 25.

10thly, To distribute, and communicate to one another necessities: give to
the poor.
If thou lend money to any of my people who is poor by thee, thou shall not be
unto them as an usurer; neither shall thou lay upon him usury, etc. Exodus 22.
25, 26.

When ye reap the harvest of your land, thou shall not wholly reap the corners
of thy fields, neither shall thou gather the gleanings of thy harvest. And thou
shall not glean thy vineyard, etc. Thou shall leave them for the poor and the
stranger. I am the Lord your God, Lev. 19. 9, 10.

If there be among you a poor man of one of thy brethen, within any of thy
gates, etc. thou shall not harden thine heart, nor shut thine hand against thy
poor brother: but thou shall open thine hand wide unto him, and shall surely
lend him sufficient for his need, in that which he wants. Beware that there
be not a thought (or, word) in thy wicked heart, saying, The seventh year, the
year of release, is at hand, and thine eye be evil against thy brother, and
thou give him naught, and he cry unto the Lord against thee, and it be sin
unto thee: thou shall surely give him, and thine heart shall not be grieved
when thou give unto him: because that for this thing the Lord thy God shall
bless thee in all thy work, etc. for the poor shall never cease out of the
land: therefore I command thee, etc. Deuteronomy. 15. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.

If I have withheld from the poor their desire, etc. or have eaten my morsel
alone, and the fatherless have not eaten thereof, etc. If I have seen any
perish for want of clothing, or any poor without covering: If his loins have
not blessed me, etc. Job 31. 16, 17, 18, 19, 20.

The righteous shows mercy, and gives, etc. He is ever merciful and lends,
Psalm. ^7. 21, 26.

Blessed is he who considers the poor (or, weak): the Lord will deliver him,
Psalm. 41. 1.

A good man shows favor, and lends, etc. He has dispersed, he has given
unto the poor, etc. Psalm. 112. 5, 9.

Say not unto thy neighbor, Go, and come again, and tomorrow I will give, when
thou have it by thee, Prove. 3. 28.

There is who scatters, and yet increases, etc. The liberal soul shall be
made fat: and he who waters shall be watered also himself, Prove. 11. 24, 25.

He who has mercy on the poor, happy is he, etc. He who oppresses the poor,
reproacheth his Maker: but he who honors him, has mercy on the poor, Prove.
14. 21, 31.

He who has pity on the poor, lends unto the Lord: and that which he has
given, will he pay him again, Prove. 19. 17.

Whosoever stops his ears at the cry of the poor, he also shall cry himself, but
shall not be heard, Prove. 21. 13.

He who has a bountiful eye shall be blessed: for he gives of his bread to
the poor, Prove. 22. 9.

He who gives unto the poor shall not lack, Prove. 28. 27.

Cast thy bread upon the waters: for thou shall find it after many days. Give a
portion to seven, and also to eight, etc. Eccles. 11. 1, 2, 3.

Is not this the fast that I have chosen, etc? Is it not to deal thy bread to
the hungry, and that thou bring the poor which are cast out, to thy house? when
thou see the naked, that thou cover him, and that thou hide not thy self from
thine own flesh? Then shall thy light break forth as the morning, etc. And if
thou draw out thy soul to the hungry, and satisfy the afflicted soul: then
shall thy light rise in obscurity, etc. Isa. 58. 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.

I have desired mercy, and not sacrifice, Hosea 6. 6.

Give to him who asks thee; and from him who would borrow of thee, turn not
away, Mat. 5. 42.

Take heed that ye do not your alms before men, to be seen of them, etc. when
thou do thine alms, do not sound a trumpet before thee, as the hypocrites
do, etc. that they may have glory of men, etc. But when thou do thine alms,
let not thy left hand know what thy right hand does, Mat. 6. 1, 2, 3.

Ask, and it shall be given you, Mat. 7. 7.

Whosoever shall give to drink unto one of these little ones, a cup of cold
water only, in the name of a disciple, verily I say unto you, He shall in no
wise lose his reward, Mat. 10. 42. Mark 9. 41.

Christ shall say, I was an hungry, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye
gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me in: Naked, and ye clothed me,
etc. when saw we thee an hungry, etc? Inasmuch as ye have done it to one of the
least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me, etc. Mat. 25. 35, 36, 37,
38, 39, 40, etc.

The poor widow threw in two mites, etc. Jesus said, This poor widow has cast
more in than all they, etc. For all they did cast in of their abundance; but
she of her want did cast in all she had, Mark 12. 42, 43, 44. Luke 21. 1, 2, 3,
4.

When thou make a feast, call the poor, the maimed, the lame, the blind: And
thou shall be blessed, for they cannot recompense thee: for thou shall be
recompensed at the resurrection of the just, Luke 14. 13, 14.

Sell all that thou have, and distribute to the poor, and thou shall have
treasure in heaven, Luke 18. 22.

The multitude of them who believed, were of one heart, etc. neither said any
of them, that ought of the things which he possessed, was his own, but they had
all things common, etc. Acts 4. 32, 34.

Cornelius a devout man, etc. who gave much alms to the people, etc. thy prayer
and thine alms are come up for a memorial before God, Acts 10. 1, 2, 4.

Then the Disciples every man according to his ability, determined to send
relief unto the brethren who dwelt in Judea, Acts 11. 29.

I have showed you all things, how that so laboring, ye ought to support the
weak, and to remember the words of our Lord Jesus, how he said, It is more
blessed to give, than to receive, Acts 20. 35.

He who gives, let him do it with simplicity (or, liberality): he who shows
mercy, with cheerfulness, etc. distributing to the necessity of the saints:
given to hospitality, etc. Romans 12. 8, 13. chapter 16. 1, 2.

It has pleased them of Macedonia, etc. to make a certain contribution for the
poor Saints, which are at Jerusalem, Romans 15. 26.

Upon the first day of the week, let every one of you lay by him in store, as
God has prospered him, 1 Cor. 16. 2.

As ye abound in all things, etc. see that ye abound in this grace also: I
speak, etc. to prove the sincerity of your love: for ye know the grace of our
Lord Jesus Christ, that though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor,
that ye through his poverty might be rich, etc. As there was a readiness to
will, so there may be a performance also, out of that which you have: for if
there be first a willing mind, it is accepted according to that a man has, and
not according to that he has not, 2 Cor. 8. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12.

He who sows sparingly, shall reap sparingly: and he who sows bountifully
shall reap bountifully. Every man according as he purposes in his heart, so
let him give, not grudgingly, or of necessity: for God loves a cheerful giver.
And God is able to make all grace abound toward you, that ye always having all
sufficiency in all things, may abound to every good work, 2 Cor. 9. 6, 7, 8, 9.

As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men, especially unto
them who are of the household of faith, Gal. 6. 10.

Rather let him labor, working with his hands the thing which is good' that ye
may have to give to him who needs, Ephesians. 4. 29.

Paul commends the Philippians for their sending to his relief: and said, Not
because I desire a gift: but I desire fruit that may abound to your account,
etc. My God shall supply all your needs, etc. Phil. 4. 14, 15, 16, 17, 12.

This we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat, etc.
We command, etc. that with quietness they work, and eat their own bread, 2 Thessalonians. 3. 10, 11, 12.

If any widow have children, or nephews, let them learn first to show pity (or,
